qas.question: When did the USSR make Russian the official language?
What unofficial status did Russian have in the USSR before 1990?

answers.text: the unifying role and superior status

qas.question: What was declared the official language of constituent republics in 1991?

plausible_answers.text: the policy toward the languages of the various other ethnic groups

qas.question: What policy fluctuated in practice in 1991?
In what year did other ethnic groups discourage native language?
In what year did constituent republics not have an official language?
What was the national discourse about in 1990?

context: During the Soviet period, <b4_0>the policy toward the languages of the various other ethnic groups<b4_0/> fluctuated in practice. Though each of the constituent republics had its own official language, <a2_0>the unifying role and superior status<a2_0/> was reserved for <b3_0>Russian<b3_0/>, although it was declared the official language only in <a1_0><b5_0><b6_0>1990<b6_0/><b5_0/><a1_0/>. Following <b7_0>the break-up of the USSR<b7_0/> in <a0_0>1991<a0_0/>, several of the newly independent states have encouraged their native languages, which has partly reversed the privileged status of Russian, though its role as the language of post-Soviet national discourse throughout the region has continued.
